image.altText: Michelle and Peter Brown pose for a photo in front of snow covered mountains

props.synopsis: Australians who say they have been left stranded overseas and broke after their travel agency collapsed have now been told the company was likely trading while insolvent.

title.children: Luxury tours off, money gone: Insolvency scandal rocks Aussie tour operator

props.synopsis: Putting aside the Coalition, let's focus on the new government: the one that has won an exceptionally large number of seats and which is probably already doing stuff that's affecting us voters.

title.children: After 45 years watching politics, I’m signing off with a final wish

image.altText: A composite image of Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and Woodside Energy's Karratha Gas Plant

props.synopsis: In a week where floods and droughts across Australia made headlines, the government extended the life of one of the world's largest gas facilities. Yet the climate did not factor into the decision.

title.children: Why is Australia approving gas projects without considering the climate?

image.altText: Donald Trump stands in front of a large steel cylinder at a us steel works factory

props.synopsis: The US President tells a rally in Pennsylvania that the increase from 25 per cent to 50 per cent will "even further secure the steel industry in the United States".

title.children: Trump says he plans to double steel tariffs to 50pc

image.altText: A pair of Birkenstock sandals on display

props.synopsis: Australian shoppers could soon see higher price tags, as brands affected by Donald Trump's tariffs prepare to increase prices beyond the US market.

title.children: Global brands plan to spread tariff price hikes beyond the US

image.altText: An overhead view of Kati Thanda-Lake Eyre.

props.synopsis: Australia’s biggest lake is believed to have reached capacity on only three occasions in the past 160 years, but the mass of floodwater now flowing into Kati Thanda-Lake Eyre is raising more than river levels.

title.children: 'Absolutely beautiful': Waters flowing into Kati Thanda-Lake Eyre a sight to behold

image.altText: two man are standing in front of a US flag and an Australian flag

props.synopsis: Australia is on track to reach defence spending levels of 2.33 per cent of GDP by 2033-34 but for months the Trump Administration has pressured the government to get to at least three per cent of GDP.

title.children: Marles open to defence spending hike after meeting Pentagon chief Hegseth

image.altText: A woman lying on the ground which is covered with leaves and flowers, mourning a death.

props.synopsis: Aboriginal people are grieving another round of sorry business in a week that is supposed to be a time for all Australians to consider their part in the enormous schisms between black and white communities.

title.children: Another Aboriginal person has left unrealised dreams and loved ones behind

image.altText: Truth telling

props.synopsis: Prominent Indigenous Australians are hopeful the federal government will progress a national truth telling process, despite PM Anthony Albanese backing down from the commitment to create a national commission.

title.children: Indigenous leaders encouraged minister open to national truth telling

image.altText: A sketch of Erin Patterson wearing a blue jumper and thin framed black glasses with her hair tied back.

props.synopsis: Erin Patterson admits lying to police about key details after a deadly lunch, but her defence claims panic — not malice — drove her actions, arguing there's no proof she intended to kill.

title.children: Erin Patterson lied about mushroom foraging but her lawyers argue she's no killer

image.altText: A woman poses for a photo while wearing a headscarf

props.synopsis: Long a no-go zone for travellers, the relative stability provided by the Taliban's return to power in Afghanistan has also meant the return of tourism.

title.children: Are travel influencers whitewashing the Taliban?

image.altText: A young boy sits on a mattress on a cement floor, holding up his prosthetic leg.

props.synopsis: Palestinian children evacuated to Jordan for medical treatment have started being sent back to Gaza, with Israeli forces confiscating their belongings on the way back into the strip.

title.children: Evacuated during ceasefire, children are being sent back to Gaza

image.altText: Composite image showing the Westfield logo, Joel Cauchi, a digital clock, a wreath with "Rest in Peace" and Amy Scott.

props.synopsis: The five-week coronial inquest into the stabbing at Bondi Junction painted a complete picture of what happened during the attack that stopped Sydney.

title.children: How the Bondi Junction Westfield stabbing attack unfolded

image.altText: An 87-year-old woman at the Golden Globes, waving and smiling.

props.synopsis: The long-serving cast member who played "Hot Lips" Houlihan of the hit TV show M*A*S*H has died.

title.children: M*A*S*H actor Loretta Swit has died, aged 87

image.altText: An eye with a blue background

props.synopsis: Russia has changed how it deployed its spy operations "to prepare for destabilisation" in Europe and react to the "counterintelligence regime" from Ukraine's allies.

title.children: A 'reckless campaign of Russian sabotage' has been uncovered. What does it mean?

image.altText: Painting titled Lieutenant John Bowen and party arriving at Risdon, by Thomas Gregson, 1860

props.synopsis: They fought to defend their land, families and culture, and drove the colonial powers to a state of panic, losing everything in the process. But Tasmanian Aboriginal resistance warriors still have no physical recognition in the state.

title.children: They resisted the world's most powerful empire, but are not recognised

image.altText: An illustration depicting two women sitting with their backs to us, in bathing suits. One is fat, the other slim.

props.synopsis: "Body-positive" content can be found all over social media. Activists say it's missing the point.

title.children: How body positivity was co-opted by brands and influencers

image.altText: A man hits a ball during a tennis match

props.synopsis: Even Alexei Popyrin didn't think he'd be the last Australian man left standing at the French Open, but now he's powered into the last 16, he's determined to make the most of it.

title.children: Alexei Popyrin makes fourth round of French Open with straight-sets win

image.altText: A woman wearing a white blouse stands outdoors with trees and grass visible in the background.

props.synopsis: Sarah Waters tried for years to quit smoking, but with cigarettes for sale everywhere, the temptation was hard to deny.

title.children: Ex-smoker backs push to ban tobacco sales at supermarkets

image.altText: A woman in a bedazzled jumpsuit

props.synopsis: Taylor Swift has bought back her life's work in a letter to fans after a feud with her former record label.

title.children: Taylor Swift buys back rights to her music

image.altText: A brick building with a bright, colourful mural depicting tropical plants and birds, a frog, and the word LIBRARY above a window

props.synopsis: Offering millions of books, free internet access and everything from craft clubs to storytelling dogs, libraries are an essential public space — particularly in regional and remote Australia.

title.children: How libraries are 'the glitter glue' binding communities together

image.altText: Kahli Johnson celebrates her goal for the Matildas on debut.

props.synopsis: Missing the likes of Sam Kerr and Mary Fowler, an inexperienced Matildas line-up defeat Argentina 2-0 in the first of their two friendlies.

title.children: Matildas debutant scores in classy win over Argentina in opening friendly

image.altText: A university graduate wearing a gown and cap is seen outside Parliament House in Canberra

props.synopsis: Labor promised to slash student debts if it won the federal election. We've answered your questions on what you need to do to have your outstanding debt reduced.

title.children: The government promised to cut my HECS debt. When will I get it?

image.altText: Katie in a white wedding gown reading vows off flash cards with Tim facing her in a suit on Married At First Sight

props.synopsis: The Black Dog Institute says gaslighting is a form of psychological manipulation that causes someone to doubt their perceptions. It's something that shows up a lot in popular culture, which gave us the word. But a US expert warns that while pop culture has given much-needed visibility to gaslighting, the word is often used too casually and at times incorrectly.

title.children: From MAFS to TikTok psychologists, gaslighting has become a buzzword

image.altText: Aivi Luik holds up her hands in a heart shape

props.synopsis: Women are claiming space in the sporting landscape, but when it comes to marketing, does their competitiveness go missing?

title.children: Is the marketing of women's sport falling short?

image.altText: A woman in a high visibility jacket, in front of a community group.

props.synopsis: Flood-affected NSW communities have banded together to set up recovery centres, deliver meals and offer a hand to their neighbours.

title.children: Flooded residents 'running on empty' as they take on recovery

image.altText: A close up of a Filipino man's face as he wears a leather wide brim hat and a grey/beige button-up shirt. Green background blur

props.synopsis: The Northern Territory is the only jurisdiction in Australia where Filipinos are the number one migrant group. Those in the tight-knit community share why they love life in the Top End.

title.children: Why so many Filipinos choose to call the NT home

image.altText: PinkPantheress sits side on in a room with dark blue curtains and leopard print wall

props.synopsis: A British pop star takes us to the 2000s, while some Aussie punks make a glorious racket.

title.children: 10 albums we couldn't stop listening to in May

image.altText: A young woman with dark hair wearing a black suit, sitting outdoors in a city street with the sun shining behind her

props.synopsis: A revealing memoir from one of Australia's most beloved authors and an exciting debut about a literary fraudster in the tradition of Helen Demidenko are among this month's best new releases.

title.children: The six books our critics couldn't put down in May

image.altText: Mid shot of a man standing in a harvested cane field

props.synopsis: Income from off-farm sources such as contract harvesting, mustering and milking will be considered "primary production" under changes to disaster funding.

title.children: Queensland redefines farmers to expand access to disaster relief

image.altText: A road leads into the mouth of a cave cut into the side of the open cut mine

props.synopsis: The state government's decision to sign off on the expansion of Victoria's largest gold mine has left some in the community "ecstatic" while others say it puts profits first.

title.children: Is Victoria's largest gold mine a good corporate citizen or bad neighbour?

image.altText: A cane toad sitting in grass

props.synopsis: Scientists use DNA to track the spread of species in major river mouths and coastal tributaries along a 1,000-kilometre stretch of the NSW coastline — revealing some surprising results.

title.children: DNA in waterways shows cane toads spreading further south in NSW

image.altText: Two men stand together in front of a herd of dairy cows on a farm, smiling at the camera.

props.synopsis: Tasmanian dairy farmers trial microbes across 500 hectares of land with the help of a "top-notch" soil biologist to reduce their reliance on synthetic fertilisers such as urea.

title.children: Farmers trial soil microbes to cut synthetic fertiliser use
